message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe localized pain, drooping eyelid, tearing eye, and rhinorrhea suggest cluster headache. The chronic shoulder pain may be a trigger for the headache. Indomethacin is used to treat cluster headaches but the patient is still experiencing pain. Migraine headaches usually do not present with drooping eyelid or tearing eye. Giant cell arteritis typically presents with headache and scalp tenderness, and it is rare in a patient this young. Medication overuse headache is unlikely as the patient has been using indomethacin as prescribed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location, characteristics, and frequency of the headache point towards cluster headache. Drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea are additional symptoms of cluster headache. Chronic shoulder pain and smoking history may be contributing factors. Indomethacin is ineffective for cluster headaches. Migraine headache usually involves nausea or vomiting, and vision disturbance, while giant cell arteritis typically affects older adults and causes scalp pain and jaw claudication. Medication overuse headache usually occurs in patients with a history of frequent use of pain medications or caffeine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe headache localized to one side of the forehead and eye, along with drooping of the eyelid, tearing of the eye, and rhinorrhea suggest cluster headache. The fact that the patient has had similar symptoms before and has chronic shoulder pain may also be relevant. Migraine headaches typically last longer and are often associated with aura and nausea/vomiting. Giant cell arteritis is unlikely given the patient's age and lack of systemic symptoms. Medication overuse headache is a possibility but less likely given that indomethacin has not provided relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe headache localized to one side of the face, drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea are characteristic of cluster headache. The fact that the patient has been using indomethacin and has chronic shoulder pain suggests that other diagnoses, such as medication overuse headache or giant cell arteritis, are less likely. Migraine headache can also present with similar symptoms, but lack the characteristic pattern and duration seen in cluster headache.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with cluster headaches, including the severe pain in the right forehead and eye, first episode in the mornings, and drooping of the right eyelid. The seeming lack of response to indomethacin may suggest cluster headaches over migraines. The tenderness to the right supraspinatus muscle suggests a possible trigger point for the headaches. The other options do not fully match the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including severe pain, localized to the right forehead and right eye, and drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea, all suggest cluster headache. Indomethacin is not effective in treating cluster headaches, and the patient's history, including chronic shoulder pain and smoking, are also consistent with the diagnosis. Migraine headache typically presents with unilateral throbbing pain, visual changes or photophobia, and is relieved by lying down in a dark and quiet room. Giant cell arteritis affects elderly patients, and can present as headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances. Medication overuse headache typically presents with daily or near-daily headaches that develop or worsen during or after the overuse of medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe headache, localized to one side, with drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and localized tenderness to the right supraspinatus muscle suggest cluster headache. Migraine headaches are also severe but usually have an aura, and medication overuse headache is not likely since the patient has not had relief with indomethacin. Giant cell arteritis causes headaches but is not typically associated with the other symptoms present.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe headache localized to the right forehead and eye along with drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea suggest cluster headache. The patient’s occupation and stress level may also contribute to the development of the headache. The use of indomethacin for pain relief is commonly used for cluster headaches but it has not provided relief. The presence of chronic shoulder pain may also suggest tension or stress-related headaches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a cluster headache, which is characterized by severe, recurrent headaches localized to one side of the head and often accompanied by symptoms such as drooping eyelid, tearing, and rhinorrhea. The chronic shoulder pain and smoking history may be contributing factors. Indomethacin is not effective for treating cluster headaches. Migraine headaches typically have other associated symptoms such as photophobia and nausea, which are not present in this case. Giant cell arteritis is usually seen in older individuals and is associated with temporal headache, fever, and tender scalp, which are not present in this case. Medication overuse headache is a possibility, but the symptoms are more consistent with cluster headache.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe headache, drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea, suggest cluster headache. The fact that the patient had similar symptoms last summer supports this diagnosis. Localized tenderness to his right supraspinatus muscle may be related to his chronic shoulder pain but is not typical of the other options. Indomethacin is commonly used to treat cluster headaches, but the lack of relief suggests that the patient needs further treatment.
